content.webTitle: Eddie Jones eyes 3-0 win for England on summer tour to Australia

fields.headline: Eddie Jones eyes 3-0 win for England on summer tour to Australia
fields.bodyText: Eddie Jones says he is targeting a 3-0 series win over Australia this summer after guiding England to their first Six Nations grand slam in 13 years. The head coach is also launching a search for a couple of new “Jonny Wilkinsons” to propel his squad further towards their goal of becoming the No1 team in the world. England’s 31-21 victory over France in Paris completed a remarkable journey from World Cup pool flops to grand slam champions but Jones is already eyeing bigger and better things. Asked what would represent a successful tour down under, he replied: “Three-nil, that’d be a super tour. Then I’d stay in Australia for a week and gloat. “Look, it is fantastic to get a grand slam, fantastic to win the Six Nations but we want to be the No1 team in the world. To do that we have to go down to Australia, beat Australia and then we will have started getting on the road. In the next two to three years we’ll have a side to beat the All Blacks.” For that to happen Jones is seeking more standout players, such as the Saracens lock Maro Itoje. “We need a few guys to come through to really push the envelope. We need them to come in, say, ‘This isn’t good enough’ and lift the level again. I’m looking for guys like a young Jonny Wilkinson. The 2003 lot still talk about when Jonny came into training as a young kid and turned the Bunsen burner up. The whole level of training increased because he had no fear and he wanted to be No1 in the world. I need to find a couple of those kids. We’ll work harder, work smarter and pick better players.” That search will begin imminently. “I’ve got to go to a Premiership game and they have got to be yelling at me to pick them. By yelling I mean they’ve got to stand out so, if you came from Mars, you’d know they’re international players.” Jones is also planning to appoint a permanent scrum coach and a temporary assistant attack coach who shares his philosophy, while Dylan Hartley is set to retain the captaincy for the Wallaby tour: “At this stage there’s no reason why Dylan won’t be captain as long as he keeps improving as a player.” England’s players, meanwhile, have hailed Jones’s input in the short period since he took over a squad that sank in the World Cup pool stages. “I think there were some great foundations from Stuart’s time but Eddie’s a world-class coach,” said the Harlequins scrum-half Danny Care, among England’s try-scorers in Paris. “He’s been there before, he’s done it, he knows how to win and he’s instilled a confidence in the team.” Jones feels the toughest part of his job has been to change the mindset of the squad in terms of their approach to games but insists the players deserve the plaudits. “We’ve gone from a team knocked out in the pool stages of a World Cup to grand slam champions. Only 13 teams in the history of English rugby have done [the latter] and the players deserve the majority of the credit for that. We just need to have more courage about the way we play. In the first half we were just sitting back a little bit. “Defensively we weren’t off the line hard and getting into them. That was probably the least physical we’ve been in the whole tournament.”
